Frustration deluxe.

Ok so the game and concept is simple, your character constantly run to the right and you have to slide, jump, kick, bounce, reflect or any of these combinations together to get to the end of the level. The music that plays in the background helps you keep the pace somewhat and you can probably blindfold this game if you memorize it completely.

But the bad thing about the game, is that you have one try.

If you fail in any way, you will start at the beginning of the level. The first few levels are easy, but the further in you get into a chapter, the levels get both longer and more complicated, some lasting up to 4-5 minutes. So the game turns into a game or memorizing every little thing, you have to remember which buttons to press and for how long to press them as well, some things you get barely no warning of at all so the first time you get there, you will die.

Fun.

So the game itself is pretty fun, except the lack of checkpoints, which makes it extremely frustrating instead.

Technically I had no real hiccups, though I experienced some light lags at times, but think it might be my computer instead of the game. 99% of the time it was smooth sailing.

So should you buy this? Well, I don’t know, some might like this a lot, perfecting levels is a wonderful feeling, but if you are forced to perfect them… Well, it just sucks the fun out of a game. This game is fun and addicting, but it has some major flaws.

First of all, the difficulty curve in this game is pretty wonky. Now, I'm not sure if this is because I got used to the game as I progressed, but I felt that some of the later stages (especially from world 2) were incredibly easy when compared to the earlier ones. The difficulty ramps up again towards the end, but you'll still find that it varies greatly from stage to stage instead of following a steadily rising curve as you would expect.

Second, while the level design will overall test your skills and reflexes, it can be a bit repetitive and sometimes very frustrating. The game will resort to artificial methods of increasing the difficulty by placing obstacles and items at very awkward positions, and since a single mistake will take you back to the beginning of the stage, that translates into annoying trial-and-error gameplay. If you don't mind having your patience tested, then you should do just fine.

And last but not least, the game has a motion blur effect that, as far as I know, cannot be disabled. I guess they chose to use this effect to give a good sense of speed and movement, but it would have been nice to include an option to disable it. Not only that effect is going to tire out your eyes  if play this game for long periods of time, but it might also cause you to fail at certain points of the game because the game's art style doesn't stand out very much — obstacles and items tend to blend in with each other, it's hard to tell them apart sometimes, and the continuous blur doesn't help one bit.

The game is still worth a shot, if you're feeling adventurous. The difficulty is insane and rage-quit inducing, and finishing a tough stage can be very satisfying. Sadly, however, I personally think that the flaws outweigh its qualities. I recommend you try the sequel, Runner2"

You can have him jump and duck to avoid obstacles, kick certain obstacles out of the way, launch himself on springboards or deflect objects with a shield. If Commander Video impacts with an obstacle, the player is forced to repeat the entire stage from the beginning. The game consists of 3 themed worlds, each with 11 stages and a boss stage.

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an indie game that, like most indie games, will leave you either wanting more or wanting your money back.

The game was developed by Gaijin Games for the Virtual Console on the Nintendo Wii in 2010, but was released on Steam in February 2011. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a rhythm-style action plaformer that consist of a protagonist, Commander Video, on a 2D plane. The player controls Commander Video as he runs along the set track from left to right and controls when the character jumps, slides, and kicking. As you progress through the 36 levels in the game (three worlds, each consisting of 11 levels, plus a boss encounter stage), you collect powerups that increase the quality of the music that plays through each level.

The game is notable for it's unique soundtrack, retro feel, and it's frustratingly difficult gameplay, as the current level is started over each time Commander Video runs into an obstacle that the player failed to acknowledge. The game forces a trial-and-error style of play, and in the end, it can hurt the experience. I myself found that I would get particularly frustrated on nearly every level that I played, as I would have to start the level over simply for pressing a button to early or too late. However, the game exceeds in rewarding the player, as the sense of accomplishment that comes from beating a particularly difficult level is unrivaled by most games that are released on the market today.

BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a unique game that can be extremely rewarding, or absolutely crushing. Be warned: the game is not for everyone. While I didn't particularly enjoy BIT.TRIP RUNNER, it continues to be a game that is loved by the Indie community and the games that follow it only stand to be a testament to their devotion.

A 5 out of 10.

Authors Note - I, personally, did not enjoy BIT.TRIP RUNNER. I felt that it was too difficult for me and that it simply wasn't my type of game. However, I do highly recommend this game to any and all gamers that have yet to play it. It's a challenging experience that harkens back to the older days of retro gaming, and for that, I can honestly say that everybody should play these games, at least once.

reviewText:
If games had voices Bit.Trip Runner would be nothing but a prolonged maniacal laugh, over the casual-friendly endless runners that permeate the mobile game market, and you the player for your thousands of clumsy failed attempts to clear a level. Runner demands absolute perfection, and in returns provides one of the most precise and satisfying games to ever grace the genre.

Although it bares many similarities to endless runners such as Canabalt, BTR is a far more deliberately structured experience than the many flash offerings available, and doesn't actually deserve to be called an endless runner as shares more in common with a rhythm game than anything else.

Each enemy, obstacle, and jump is timed directly to the music playing behind it, an integral fact that is critical in landing your timing and predicting what is coming down the line. As you dodge these hurdles you in turn add your own portion of the soundtrack, fleshing out the melody and adding new layers to each track. Nailing a run perfectly is exhilarating, all the more so because doing so requires such finesse and determination.

It should be noted and re-noted that BTR is a very, very hard game, perhaps the most difficult one in fact that I have ever successfully completed. It is brutally unforgiving from the onset and doesn't hesitate to send you right back to the start of the level over the tiniest slip-up. There are no checkpoints at any point in the game, and as levels become longer the trial and error design calls for some serious memorization and hand eye coordination.

I don't doubt for a second that most will not complete the game, perhaps not even the first would. It's a grueling task that appeals to a specific sect of masochistic gamers which, although I personally love it to death, is the reason I simply cannot recommend the game to anyone who isn't ready for an immense challenge. Everyone else will find a far better time skipping straight to Runner 2, which is all around a much more easily enjoyable game regardless of skill level.

Level variety is also a bit of a problem, as with only three different worlds you will be spending a lot of time looking at the same things, and overcoming the same obstacles. This isn't such a bad thing as the music and art are excellent across the board, but it did begin to wear on me after spending so long stuck in the same place. Another minor problem is that for the later two worlds the backgrounds become so congested, that they sometimes obscure obstacles coming toward you which is highly frustrating and one of the few parts of the game that just feels cheap.

No matter these smaller problems I still adore Bit.Trip Runner. The way the music ties into the gameplay gives it a unique feel and keep the experience feeling fair no matter how often I failed at it. The electronic soundtrack perfectly complements the style of gameplay, and the way it all comes together is much more consistently great than likely any Bit.Trip game that came before it. There is something to be said for the difficulty turning many players away (and you would be right to do so if that isn't your cup of tea), but for those unafraid to attempt to conquer the laborious challenge it presents, Runner is easily worth a try and for provides a sense of personal accomplishment that other games can't.

It's Meh

I've heard lots of good things about this game, so I bought it during the Steam Winter Sale. I did not enjoy this game. At first, the game was pretty fun, and I liked it, though I noticed a delay from when I hit a key to when the game responded (I had no lag/framedrop during the time of play) so it made the game difficult to stay on beat, so I found myself starting over quite a bit. This could just be my keyboard, so I don't know. Also, there are no checkpoints. At all. So one little mistake, one little off-beat press of a button, and you are sent all the way back through that 5 minute level you just drudged through.

The game itself is a music/rythm platforming game, however I wouldn't call it a rythm game. It feels more like a memory game. Throughout the game, you must jump, kick, slide, bounce, and reflect to reach the end of the stage. The graphics made me felt like I was going crosseyed while I played, they look good, but they don't mix well with a moving foreground. It made it unenjoyable, and I got headaches from it. This, mixed with the whole jumping and kicking, made it nearly impossible for me to even see what was going on. The rounds would drag on, and on. So, I had to memorize the course, while the backround remains stationary with a moving foreground, with a delay on me hitting buttons.

Here is the most enjoying part. The music. I loved it, except, every time you die, you get sent back to the beginning. Meaning that the music starts over with it. BUT.

I must remind you all that Runner 2 is actually the odd member of the family. Apart from it, ALL Bit.Trip games are this mercyless, and even more (in fact, the Runner games are the easiest ones from the franchise IMO). So Bit.Trip Runner is just another game similar to all those from the same company. It's not fair at all to compare it with a game that has very few in common if you look coldly.

Personally, the Runner's games are the only ones from this franchise that I enjoyed. And if you have to choose one of them, it's just a matter of interests: if you wanna beat a real challenge and prove yourself you can face a hard game, try Runner 1; if you want to enjoy those kind of arcade games where you main purpose is avoiding things without getting frustrated, try Runner 2. I suggest playing both though.

In conclusion, you'll read many positive and negative reviews, and all of them will be true. This game is simply not made for everybody, only for people who enjoys challenges from videogames, while its sequel is suitable for everybody.

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a game that hails to the pre-NES gaming era. This game has the player performing well timed jumps, slides and other moves, usually in a rhythmic fashion, to collect gold bars and avoid obstacles. BIT.TRIP RUNNER was a well received game and it seems that this game has a lot of indie cred but my experience playing this game contrasted to what I hear in the reviews has me wondering if I'm playing the right game or if I need to drill down into an option menu somewhere to enable the good content. The art style is distinctive and appealing and the game itself does have it's moments, however it forces you to endure quite a bit of tedium to get to a meager portion of enjoyable gameplay.

BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a game that requires very price timing and rythmn and a single half-second delay will mean restarting the level in most cases. The first 20 seconds or so of each level will insult you by being boring and unchallenging and due to the nature of this game that first 20 seconds of gameplay will be what you experience most as any mishap will transport you back to the beginning. I'm not advocating making the game easier as I appreciate a challenge but I don't appreciate being forced to repeat uninteresting gameplay several times over.  Many levels seem to be laden with challenges that can be fun at first but are repeated ad nauseum and end up feeling like a gimmick (for instance there will be a staircase in almost every level that requires consecutive jumps). These challenges quickly become tedius and only serve as a mechanism to return you once again to the boring part of the level. Levels can get quite long too so the chances you'll be repeating uninteresting gameplay is quite high.

I've read comments about the game's soundtrack and the menu options do feature Anamanaguchi in the menu and credits the actual game's music is boring most of the time as it requires progress in the level to become interesting. I wonder why the game's music didn't feature Anamanaguchi as well.

If you're looking for a game that's challenging and requires a high level of precision and quick reactions, although the format is different, other popular indie titles like Super Meat Boy and VVVVVV do a better job. Super Meat Boy's short levels and VVVVVV's room based format allow these games to respect the player's time.

Score: 5/10

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP RUNNER
A throwback to the 8bit era of fiendishly tricky platform games, reminiscent of games like Jumping Jack on the ZX Spectrum.

Rating 5/10

The first thing you'll learn about BIT.TRIP RUNNER is that it's a game that requires perfect timing and precision as well having to memorise level layouts and obstacles as there are no checkpoints and that each level has to be completed in a single run as failure returns you to the beginning of the level.

This requirement of a perfect run is both what makes and breaks Bit.Trip Runner. At its best it's a gloriously fluid experience as you meticulously learn the obstacles on a level and the feeling of exhilaration when you manage to pull of a perfect run.

However it's also at times an incredibly frustrating experience. There are a handful of levels that are too long which can lead to extended attempts to the point of quitting and some obstacles require such pin-point precision that means failure towards the end of the level is a maddening experience as you watch your character revert back to the start. However if you stick with it your perseverance is rewarded.

There is much to recommend in Bit.Trip runner, from the visuals, music and the challenge but I would only recommend it to those who like an old fashioned challenge, for those who like their games to be unforgiving and to reward patience and practise as well as precision.

reviewText:
I've only played the first eight or so levels but I think I'm ready to give my opinion. I can only describe it as a beautifully executed bad idea. The game is lovely, the graphics are lovely, the sounds are lovely, the animations are lovely, the implementation of the 2.5D is lovely, the controls are lovely. The game behind it all... well again the implementation is good with nice responsive controls and snappy resets to the start of the level that don't break up the flow when you fail. Unfortunately the core idea behind it all is actually pretty weak. The rest of the game is constantly making up for that but it can never quite overcome the fact that if you look behind the curtain at what is happening mechanically there isn't much fun to be had there. What is really annoying is that one or two minor changes would have made it sooo much better.

On the surface it looks like a standard auto-runner but these are set levels rather than anything randomly generated and they have ends that must be reached to progress and ultimately, if you have the patience, beat the game. The problem is that once you've learnt the controls and learnt to read the meaning of the obstacle you must pass (pit means jump, step means jump, high UFO means duck, low UFO means jump etc) then it becomes just an exercise in pressing the right sequence of buttons with the right timing. You can see what buttons presses will be required next just as surely as if they were presented as flying towards you as they are in Guitar Hero type games. So what is there left to do? Just mindlessly try and try until you succeed in getting the timing right. The music and visuals effectively distracted from the essential boredom of this exercise for awhile but ultimately life is too short.

Now how could it have been better. Well when you pass an obstacle it plays a certain little chime that combines with the background beat to make a little song and that is lovely. It would have been great to see that combined into the game somehow so that you could use the audio cues to help with the timing of your jumps. Or if the button presses had sounds associated with them that you had to insert into the tune at the right moments and thus complete the tune then I think the game would have really come alive. As it is the game is more fun to watch and listen to then actually play.

reviewText:
Be prepared to develop an extreme love-hate relationship with BIT.TRIP RUNNER. It's an excellent side-scrolling platformer, but it's relentlessly unforgiving and hard as hell. Be warned upfront: there are no check points! In retrospect it works well and fits the game, check points would have made it too easy and casual - if that's what you're after then grab RUNNER 2.

In many ways this game throws me back to the 80s in its simplicity, but it retains a modern gaming appeal and atmosphere that will keep you coming back for more and more... and more... and more. It's one of those 'just one more try' games. The modern take on 8 bit graphics is really good and brings the world to life. The music is great and never became repetitive like some people mentioned in their reviews. In fact, the music was one of the highlights of the game for me and always set the perfect mood.

BIT.TRIP RUNNER occupies a pretty unique space when compared to typical platformers, and I can't think of any other game that competes with it head on. It's perfect for short, fun bursts of gaming and is guaranteed to test your platforming skills, no matter how seasoned you think you are. If you're in two minds about buying it, take the plunge. It's selling at the right price and well worth the money. If you can pick it up on special then it's an absolute no-brainer... even if it's not on special, I'd consider it a must buy and must play.

reviewText:
BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an interesting retro-looking, rhythm & platforming game. The game starts out simple enough, the first few levels only requiring one to use the jump button, adding a kick, duck/slide and block (certain projectiles only) later on.
There are 3 difficulties to choose from, Easy, Normal & Perfect. Unfortunately, Normal was testing my patience before I was halfway thru the first zone. The reason being: there are no checkpoints during the levels. None. Sometimes this isn't that big of a deal, but when attempting the last couple of levels in a zone it's incredibly annoying because these levels are way longer than the others.
Upon completion of a level perfectly (by grabbing all the gold & the plus shaped power-ups), a bonus level awaits with graphics like that of the Atari classic, Pitfall. In these bonus levels one hit and it's over. There's no restarting at the beginning. You will have to complete the level perfect again to try the bonus level and aim for a perfect on it.
RUNNER consists of three zones of 11 levels (and a bonus level for each one) plus a boss level, which could have you spending quite a bit of time trying to get perfects on everything.

Recommended, but be warned that the lack of checkpoints and the frustrating difficulty might not be for everyone.

reviewText:
I've only played the first eight or so levels but I think I'm ready to give my opinion. I can only describe it as a beautifully executed bad idea. The game is lovely, the graphics are lovely, the sounds are lovely, the animations are lovely, the implementation of the 2.5D is lovely, the controls are lovely. The game behind it all... well again the implementation is good with nice responsive controls and snappy resets to the start of the level that don't break up the flow when you fail. Unfortunately the core idea behind it all is actually pretty weak. The rest of the game is constantly making up for that but it can never quite overcome the fact that if you look behind the curtain at what is happening mechanically there isn't much fun to be had there. What is really annoying is that one or two minor changes would have made it sooo much better.

On the surface it looks like a standard auto-runner but these are set levels rather than anything randomly generated and they have ends that must be reached to progress and ultimately, if you have the patience, beat the game. The problem is that once you've learnt the controls and learnt to read the meaning of the obstacle you must pass (pit means jump, step means jump, high UFO means duck, low UFO means jump etc) then it becomes just an exercise in pressing the right sequence of buttons with the right timing. You can see what buttons presses will be required next just as surely as if they were presented as flying towards you as they are in Guitar Hero type games. So what is there left to do? Just mindlessly try and try until you succeed in getting the timing right. The music and visuals effectively distracted from the essential boredom of this exercise for awhile but ultimately life is too short.

Now how could it have been better. Well when you pass an obstacle it plays a certain little chime that combines with the background beat to make a little song and that is lovely. It would have been great to see that combined into the game somehow so that you could use the audio cues to help with the timing of your jumps. Or if the button presses had sounds associated with them that you had to insert into the tune at the right moments and thus complete the tune then I think the game would have really come alive. As it is the game is more fun to watch and listen to then actually play.

reviewText: This is an semi-rhythm, auto-scrolling platformer where you time your actions to avoid death.  Your basic actions are jump, kick, block, and duck -- and combinations of those.  Pretty simple stuff, but the challenging part is to do this quickly without too much error.  This is really a test of hand-eye coordination and memory (due to the levels being the same each time).  Rhythm and music are a key part of this game, but the game also relies on non-rhythmic actions as well.  As for any negatives, I have read some complaints about levels not having check points.  The lack of level check points is actually part of the appeal!  But do consider that the levels take no more than three minutes to complete so it's not as if you are losing a lot of invested time here when you die.  And speaking of dying, you will die a lot but in a fun and challenging way.  In the end, this is one of those games that doesn't look all that fun until you actually play it.  I've fallen in love with this game, and indeed, it is highly addictive!

reviewText:
I wish I could recommend this game. The idea is really cool especially for something that seems like it may be limited since it's a rail platformer. But there are problems... a lot of problems.

Graphics: Look, I'm not going to complain about the graphics being 8bit. That's the style the game wanted to take itself (for the most part), and I'm ok with that. I actually like the basic look of the character and some of the 8bit objects in the world are pretty cool looking too. But then you have to realize that this is a game where the character never stops running. The background, the foreground, the obstacles you have to dodge... it just gets vomit inducing. It just looks so blurry that it hurts to look at this game for very long, and I'm somebody that doesn't get motion sickness very easy. If you get powerups, then the screen pretty much flashes every time you grab a gold piece. In a game where you have to have your eyes taped open to make sure you don't blink and miss a jump, having distractions like that is unforgivable.

Gameplay: It's simple, and actually provides entertainment to an extent. At first, it's fun to get pass the slightly challenging obstacles. It feels nice to pass something that seems really difficult on your first try. The problem is this game is seriously one of the most repetitive games I've ever played in my life. I guess you could say a rail platformer that uses only a few buttons will inevitably be pretty repetitive, but they could've done much more with this game. If you play the game and come across a slightly challeging obstacle, you can be damn sure that you'll be doing that same exact obstacle twenty more times through the rest of the game (that's assuming you complete the rest of the game in a perfect run, which you won't)

Replayability Value: As stated above, this game is repetitive. At first, it's repetitive because it's really easy, and not much can be done to change the repitition. Later on, it's repetitive because the level design lacks creativity and just rehashes the same things from the last few levels. After that, starting at about world 3-9, it's repetitive because you get killed by something that's actually a new challenge. Then you hit world 3-10 and it's repetitive because that new challenge is being milked for all its worth and is thrown into the next level 4 times and you get killed after completing it because you misjumped and hit the edge of a staircase. So, the replayability value is bad. Keep in mind, this is a game that forces you to start at the beggining of a level after one screw up. Yeah...

Soundtrack: At first, I liked the soundtrack. It was interesting and kept me playing the game despite its lackluster gameplay. But just like the level design, they got lazy. The soundtrack sounds the same throughout the entire game. There may be slight changes, but it still sounds so bland after playing for a while. You get a headache from the ugly background, the repetitive music, and the fact that you have to keep playing the beggining of every level 200 hundred times because you can't get through these levels like a robot.

Difficulty: Don't even get me started. Personally, this game bored the hell out of me until much later. I'll admit, 1-11 was hard because it was a couple of minutes long, and making a perfect run over a few minutes isn't easy, but I still got through it after several tries. Then the game got boring again. It got boring because the obstacles that I was coming across were the same obstacles I came across ten times in the last map. All of the sudden, I got to 3-9 and out of nowhere the game decided to throw, by far, the hardest obstacles the game has to offer. There was no warning, no slowly scaling diffculty leading up to this point, it just went haywire out of nowhere. But, luckily, it was at the very beggining of the round, so I had a good chance to practice and practice. Finally, I perfected it! Eventually I got pass the level, and even though it was difficult, I stayed positive and continued into the next level. I get through half of the level filled with obstacles I've seen before just to be greeted by this same ♥♥♥♥ing obstacle from 3-9. Then eventually I get to 3-11, and the same ♥♥♥♥ing obstacle once again. I played throughout this entire game and feel like I've only really played 4 different levels.

And, don't get me wrong, I don't hate this game because I died a lot. I love Super Meat Boy and that game infuriates me to no end. The difference between this and SMB is that SMB had good level design. They implemented some obstacles you've seen before but they did it in new, clever ways. This game does no such thing. You just do what you did before.

I wanted to like this game, but it has only provided me dissapointment and infuriation. Opinions are subjective, so take what you will from this review, but if I could do it all over again I wouldn't even get this game for free, it's just a waste of time that I've only put so many hours into because I'm obsessed with completing it.

BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a one-trick pony, like many indie games.

It's a platformer with a neat 8-bit techno soundtrack. Your character runs at a fixed speed, and has to avoid obstacles by jumping, sliding, and kicking. The moves you make are timed to the beat of the soundtrack. That's kind of neat. However, when you miss a jump, slide, or kick, you have to go back to the beginning of the level. That part is not so neat, it's super-annoying.

It may not be fair, but it's hard not to compare this game to other recent super-difficult retro indie platformers, like VVVVVV and Super Meat Boy. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a lesser game than those. It's just not very fun.

reviewText:
Bit.Trip.Runner is one of those games you'll come back to quite frequently for a quick run through just to enjoy the music and basic gameplay.

Gameplay mechanics are standard and timing is everything, but not too intimidating. You'll quickly learn the progressive controls and be hopping, sliding, and kicking with ease. The challenge with the game comes with having to be 100% accurate. One mis-step of timing failure and it's back to the start of the level. Some may say this isn't a big deal, but the levels get quite long and so you quickly realize the smallest flaw killed you mere feet from the finish line.

The soundtrack is what truly makes this game standout though. Music is of course a subjective thing, but the gameplay mixed with the semi-chiptune soundtrack made this an engaging experience.

reviewText:
Despite my eternal hatred towards this game's graphic, I'll try to write... objectively. I hope.

Gameplay: similar to Super Meat Boy. Frustrating and requires you to practice so you can get through a level. I was stuck like 30 minutes trying to beat 1-4 level, of which I nearly threw the towel in and uninstalled the game.

You control an ugly character that can run forward. At first you can only make him jump, but as you progress deeper he can slide and kick. How he can keep on sliding and kicking endlessly while running is beyond my logic though. Unlike SMB, your char runs forward automatically, so you just need to concentrate on kicking jumping and sliding to avoid the walls / obstacles.

Level designs can be incredibly tedious, as you keep on repeating moves you do in the first one-third of the level and repeat and repeat it. However, because of that, learning curve isn't that steep. As you memorize the first one-third, the rest is pretty easy.

Game has NO checkpoint. If you die one second before you reach the finish line, you will repeat the entire level. No question asked. Imagine if it happened to you? I felt it many times, don't worry, I know the feeling.

Graphic: no further comment or I'll look like a complete hater. I even have problem reading the menus.

Sound: Okay, I guess. I am not a fan but I don't dislike it either. Pretty fitting for the game.

Replayability: Based on levels I've finished, it's close to zero. Unless you want to fix your score, then there's no reason to play previous levels.

And lastly, as far as I'm aware of, no proper controller support for Dinput gamepads. Even when I try to attach x360ce the game doesn't recognize it. I don't know which one is wrong - as that emulator can hook my controller perfectly for many games.

Buy it or not? I personally would just think this game is a bundle material. And certainly for 10 bucks it is too expensive. Maybe a hardcore fan of Bit Trip games is alright I guess.

reviewText:
I really, really disliked this game. BIT.TRIP RUNNER takes the mechanics of The Impossible Game and cranks it up to 11. However, whereas The Impossible Game was simplistic, BTR is punishing and convoluted.

You have a few different commands mapped to different keys (or buttons if you're on a controller) such as ducking, jumping, kicking, etc. Depending on the upcoming obstacle, you have to do one of those. However, the game is sorta 2.5D, and there's a very annoying effect in some instances (especially concerning stairs) where the camera will move enough for you to lose a bit of accuracy in your timing.

Like The Impossible Game, interacting with something will send you to the beginning of the stage. Thank goodness the stages are much shorter, because after crashing into the same exact wall 10 times, I don't think I could have dealt with the level going on for much longer of a distance than that.

The pickups in the level are pointless. After getting them all, you get a rainbow behind your character, but it doesn't seem to do anything at all. Otherwise, they just add points, but they're so easy to get that everyone must have the same score on every level that doesn't include other methods of getting points.

Overall, I had a terrible time with this game, and I would rather wait for The Impossible Game to get off of Greenlight than recommend this to a friend.

reviewText: Bit.Trip Runner was designed by someone who likes listening to music and jumping in videogames, but unfortunately they just decided to smash the two together and call it a day without htinking about the implications. The music in Bit.Trip Runner is synchronized with the game, so when your character jumps over an obstacle, a note plays, but the note plays when you clear the obstacle, not when you start the jump, so if you're musically inclined and start to jump with the rhythm of the music, you'll always jump too late and have to start over at the beginning of the level. Basically, if you can carry a tune, you're boned, because the instant you try to become one with the beat, you lose.

reviewText:
It's the Boku No Pico of videogames.

How? That's rather difficult to explain. As a platformer it's frustrating, unfair, the controls are loose, the music is repetitive, level design is grating...but despite its numerous faults if you let it the game will suck you in for hours on end. No matter how it might enrage the player, it is *very* difficult to stop playing. To say a game is that compelling sure sounds like a great compliment, but I assure you it's not. Anger sets in after the first few minutes and builds--not declines--with each successive level. It's a Simon Says at a million miles an hour, forcing the player to perform a series of monotonous tasks to a degree of precision in the milliseconds, and there's not a moment's respite for failure. Expect to see the beginning of each level many times. While the challenge and satisfaction of success could make the game very rewarding for the few willing to take the time to master its nuance, it's plagued by control issues. Suffice to say, the input feels unacceptably loose and many times the player can expect to have quite a defeats snatched from the jaws of victory by a missed keypress or delay of only a few frames. This I cannot overstate: the game expects the player to perform to a level that it itself cannot reach. So why persist? It's succubus! The level isn't *that* hard. You can't be *that* bad at such a simple game. You were *so* close that last attempt. Surely you'll get it *this* time. It's just enough to keep playing, but not enough to feel any satisfaction for a victory.

Maybe I'm nitpicking, but I can't bring myself to recommend a game that demands so much from the player, but isn't precise enough to handle the players it's trying to court. With a little refinement and some tighter controls, I could see this as a great Super Hexagon or Audiosurf-alike, but that's simply not the case.

reviewText:
This has bad design all over it.

Your character always runs right and you have to jump at the right time to avoid obstacles. This is a simple game, but it works against you in a way that is just dependent on your abilities as a gamer.

I won't say that the game sucks because you don't know what's coming ahead of you and it's all about memorization. Some people won't like that, I'm not the biggest fan, but I play retro games made that way and manage to find them fun if they feature good design otherwise (good controls, level design, enemy behavior, etc.).

The game sucks because while the camera is often placed fine, there are very important moments when the action gets fast and you have to make a sudden fall to avoid an obstacle at the top, at those moments the camera stays in place and doesn't give you the focus necessary on the bottom part. (One might not know what I'm talking about if they didn't play later levels.)

And you'll notice a ton of moments when the game is slightly buggy or the controls suddenly don't respond in an optimal way. I wonder how I got through the game at all.

I heard Runner2 is an improvement in many ways, in fact a great game. The first game though, it's frustrating for all the wrong reasons and that's coming for a retro gaming fan like me.

reviewText:
Ohhh BIT TRIP !! This is in my opinion the best in the BIT-TRIP series,other BT games are based around different styles of gameplay and this one is all about running without dying,it's fast paced and will have you shouting at the screen of unfair pixels grrrr anyway I enjoy runner style games like that of the warioware series and others,this however is the best and is very challenging,my only complaint is that I would sometimes like to speed up and slow down the gameplay at the cost of a time bar or something like that,a good idea for BIT-TRIP 3 !

I play this game every other day and find myself coming back for more even when the challenge can be really tough at times and I feel like smashing the screen in,I take a break and come back to it so it must be good ! The game also sounds great however there is no audio timing to gameplay sync like you are led to believe from other reviews but it's still a fun run.

There are plenty of hidden goodies including many steam awards for playing and that keeps me going when I get a bit angry with the brutal difficulty that some of the levels display,I am on world 2,the first boss was a nightmare and the pace seems to have calmed down to introduce new play mechanics,I might also add that world 2 is quite refreshing to look at after being stuck on world one for so long.

I will also note that I am playing the game on normal difficulty,I didn't know it could be set to easy and I would recommend others to keep it on normal,my 6 year old also plays this game and he can also complete quite a few of the stages and like me,he is also addicted to the daily BIT-TRIP play through challenge.

Great game that all old school arcade lovers should play,if you like a solid challenge that is also fun and rewarding then get this game and have some fun but be prepared to also shout at it grrr

8/10 !!

I suggest you skip this one and play Runner 2 instead.

reviewText: BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a fun little musical platformer. Unfortunately, the game has several problems. For one, Gaijin Games doesn't seem to know about the concept of a proper difficulty curve. The difficulty is all over the place. Some levels are hard, some levels are easy, and some levels are just disproportionately hard. Odyssey is one level that comes to mind, as several people haven't even gone past that level, if you check the achievements page. Another problem is that this game is only fun if you are good at it. Otherwise, it's just frustrating. And even if you are doing well, making one little mistake forces you to start the entire level over, which can be incredibly frustrating if it was a long level, and just plain disheartening if you keep making mistakes in a level. And one of the more glaring flaws, is how bonus levels are handled. You get to those after getting all the gold in a level. Unfortunately, you only have one try at them. If you fail, and want to try again to perfect the level, you have to play through the regular level all over again, just to get one shot at the bonus. reviewText:
Think you're good at rhythm games? Think again. This retro-style rhythm-them-up puts your mind inside the music and has you pressing the different keys at the right time to dodge the oncoming obstacles. The soundtrack in each level is different and incredibly funky.
The levels are all predetermined so you can be sure that when you fail, your immediate cry of “♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t!” is not at all justified. After a few levels of pulling off some sick moves, you can really check out your skills it BIT.TRIP RUNNER, and reaching the end of a tough challenge is very rewarding. There are gold coins to pick up along the way that naturally increase your score and clearing a level of gold will send you to an bonus challenge. Here you get no backing track, so you have to face the music (LOL) and make up the rhythm in your head, which is difficult even on the early bonuses.
The best thing about this game is the steadily intensifying backing track, and each time you collect a special pickup it gets louder and more involved. It’s also a great way of knowing if you’re near the end of a level, because of the intense bass after all those pickups.
Whether you’re tone deaf or fancy yourself as a bit of a musician, this game will keep you raving (and raging) all day long. And no, it’s not better than Rhythm Paradise.
